item.content:encoded:
Why did I start learning Vim?

It started as a simple curiosity.
A few days ago, Vim was only a program that forced me to reboot my computer when I first started exploring the Linux OS.

Initially, I wasn't sure how Vim could enable a writer to be noticeably more capable at the keyboard. I understood that using your mouse was inefficient, but I still didn't understand how Vim was more efficient.

I dabbled a little bit; learned how to use "HJKL" to move the cursor, but I wasn't impressed. So once again, I put the idea of learning aside.

I've learned a lot since

Since then, my abilities as a developer have surpassed my initial ambitions; but I haven't looked back at Vim till recently.

Vim came back into my consciousness when I came across a Reddit forum of Vim enthusiasts explaining how the text editor allowed them to increase their output at the keyboard.

I remained skeptical, reminded of my initial experiences using Vim
until I read this article. I realized that Vim didn't have one specific feature that allowed users to become more efficient. Instead, it's the ridiculous amount of ways a skilled Vim user can edit text that gave Vim its merit ( these features even include Regular Search Expressions! ).

Quickly, I concluded that Vim was worth learning, but I'd have to go in cold turkey. Learning the workflow half-ass would be a slow, painful and inefficient process.

The results to date

Two weeks in, I love it! I'm not too sure if I'm faster, but I think I've at least matched my previous output. On top of that, I've found enjoyment in something I didn't previously have. Typing used to be a means to an end, but Vim made it a fun activity.

I imagine beginning calligraphists feel something similar.

FYI this article was written and edited using the Vim plugin in VScode, and I imagine that subsequent articles will as well.
